High fatty alcohol production (>90 % selectivity) can be achieved though the selective hydrogenation of fatty acid methyl esters over layered double hydroxide derived CuMgAlO x catalysts in a fixed-bed reactor at 250 °C under atmospheric H2. ∼17 wt.% Cu loading CuLDHs with different Mg2+/Al3+ ratios (CuMg60Al40O x , CuMg70Al30O x , CuMg75Al25O x , and CuMg80Al20O x ) were prepared by co-precipitation-hydrothermal method. The Cu dispersion and species were determined by H2-TPR, consecutive H2-TPR, N2O-dissociative reaction, and in situ TR-XANES. Highly dispersed Cu metal along with cationic Cu(I) species were obtained for all CuMgAlO x . The cationic Cu(I) species (Cu+/Cu+-H) content increased with Mg2+ content. In the presence of H2, the cationic Cu(I) species undergo reversible interconversion between Cu+ and Cu+-H species, facilitating hydrogen dissociation/evolution. The hydrogenation activity was governed by the balance of the metallic Cu surface and the cationic Cu(I) species. The Cu+ species allow preferential adsorption of CO ester for selective hydrogenation of FAMEs to fatty alcohol (>90 % selectivity). With Cusurface/Cu(I) ratio at 0.25 (CuMg75Al25O x ), the fatty alcohol production rate of 49.3 h−1 was obtained with high stability due to the reversible interconversion of Cu+/Cu+-H that prevented product re-adsorption and side reactions. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Cationic Cu(I) species Reversible interconversion Cu+/Cu+-H species CuLDHs Fatty alcohol FAMEs Selective hydrogenation Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Fatty alcohols, also known as long-chain alcohols (C12–C18), are essential chemicals widely utilized across various industries. Their applications include serving as surfactants, plasticizers, solvents, flavorings, detergents, foam stabilizers, and ingredients in cosmetics, plastic intermediates, paints, and coatings [1,2]. In fact, ∼5500 tons of fatty alcohols are consumed (∼ $ 8.5 billion market) [3,4]. Petroleum-based fatty alcohols are typically through hydroformylation and subsequently selective hydrogenation, involving the combination of CO, H2, and paraffins [5–8]. Though these processes are neither sustainable nor and environmentally friendly. Alternatively, bio-based fatty alcohols can be produced by the selective hydrogenation of fatty acid methyl esters (FAMEs), which are derived from triglycerides present in renewable sources, such as vegetable oils (palm and soybean), waste cooking oils, and animal fats. With the drive toward carbon neutrality, the price of bio-based fatty alcohols ($2500 to $6000 per metric ton) is twice of the petroleum based long-chain alcohols ($1500 to $3000 per metric ton) [9–12]. This leads to a higher margin for the bio-based fatty alcohols. Hence, the hydrogenation of FAMEs to fatty alcohols is a key sustainable approach to converting renewable feedstocks, which contributes to carbon neutrality [13,14]. Copper-chromite (CuO/CuCr2O4) catalysts are commercially used for the selective hydrogenation of FAMEs to fatty alcohols under high temperatures (200–400 °C) and pressure (200–300 bar of H₂) [15–17]. However, the toxicity related to chromium leaching under harsh reaction conditions leads to complicated waste management and environmental concerns. While, non-noble metal catalysts with less toxicity, such as Ni/SiO₂ [18,19], Ni-Fe/Al₂O₃ [20], Co/SiO₂-Al₂O3 [21], and Co/SiO₂ [22], tend to promote decarbonylation to olefinic products with one carbon shorter chain length, leading to a lower alcohol selectivity. In addition, these catalysts are prone to deactivation due to CO poisoning and coke formation which further limits their long-term efficiency. Despite a poor metal dispersion observed in the impregnated Cu catalysts, the copper-based catalysts exhibit significantly low decarbonylation and decarboxylation activities and are highly selective for alcohol production [23,24]. To obtain highly dispersed and stabilized Cu nanoparticles, a strong metal support interaction or sophisticated preparation is required. However, supported Cu over typical reducible metal oxides, such as TiO2 and CeO2, shows a dramatically low activity due to the electron deficiency of the Cu surface induced by those reducible metal oxides [24–29]. Alternatively, copper phyllosilicate offers high Cu dispersion (>65 %) over non-reactive support. This could be attributed to the strong interaction between Cu-SiO2 in the octahedral sites of chrysocolla structures, which leads to the formation of Cu+ species retained in the catalysts [30–32]. In fact, the presence of Cu+ species enhanced the Cu dispersion, presumably preventing the Cu agglomeration, which further increase the activity [30–34]. The Cu+ species also promote η1-adsorption of CO, preventing the decarbonylation and decarboxylation. Moreover, Cu+ species can promote the produced alcohol desorption and prevent alcohol re-adsorption, leading to a high alcohol selectivity [30,31]. Nevertheless, Brønsted acid sites (BAS) derived from the interaction of silanols at the Cu perimeters promote the dehydration of alcohol to olefins as side products and also cause deactivation [30]. The attempt to improve alcohol selectivity with alkali metal doping to neutralize those BAS can only increase the alcohol selectivity up to 60 % [31]. Alternatively, copper layered double hydroxides (CuLDHs) feature positively charged brucite-like layers (brucite-like M(OH)6-octahedral, M = Cu2+, Mg2+, and Al3+) and interlayer anions. The Mg2+/Al3+ ratio within these octahedral layered structures governs not only the basicity of the CuLDHs but also the interaction between Cu and support (Cu-MgO and Cu-Al2O3) [35]. This strong interaction of copper within confined metal oxide sheets would readily affect the Cu reducibility, Cu0/Cu+ generation, and Cu dispersion after the reduction [33,36]. Accordingly, the basic catalysts with highly dispersed Cu0/Cu+ species could be obtained from LDHs derived CuMgAlO x catalysts for high selectivity of fatty alcohols from FAMEs hydrogenation. In a supportive manner, Cui G., et al. showed that the LDHs derived CuMgAlO x (Mg2+/Al3+ = 1.0) showed >99 % ethylene glycol from selective hydrogenation of dimethyl oxalate [37]. Accordingly, the ultra-fine Cu nanoparticles with Cu0/Cu+ in the confined mixed oxide sheets could show distinct hydrogen dissociation, adsorption, and evolution, as typically observed for those M0/M+ species. For example, AgHZSM-5 showed the reversible interconversion between Ag0 and Ag+ [38]. Under H2, the exchangeable Ag+ was reduced forming Ag0 with nearby acid sites (BAS). The dissociated H over Ag° could reversibly react with BAS back to exchangeable Ag+, evolving H2 under inert. The dimeric extra-framework gallium species ([Ga2O2]2+) can dissociate hydrogen forming Ga+-H that reversibly evolves hydrogen under an inert atmosphere [39]. In addition, the heterolytic dissociation of hydrogen over atomically dispersed Cu derived from Cu containing LDHs, presumably forming Cuδ+-H, has been mentioned [32]. The reversible interconversion in LDHs derived CuMgAlO x , especially Cu+-H species, could promote selective hydrogenation of the carbonyl compounds (aldehydes and esters) in a manner similar to typical hydride species. Furthermore, the simultaneous hydrogen dissociation/evolution over the active catalyst surface could prevent carbon deposition, prolonging the catalyst's lifetime. With this regard, the selective hydrogenation of methyl palmitate (MP) to long-chain alcohol (hexadecanol) over LDHs derived CuMgAlO x catalysts, was investigated in a continuous fixed-bed reactor under atmospheric H2 pressure. 17 wt.% CuLDHs with various Mg2+/Al3+ ratios were tested for structural stability, reducibility, and Cu dispersion. The Cu+/Cu0 species and their reversible interconversion were characterized by consecutive H2-TPR, N2O-dissociative reaction, and in situ TR-XANES, from which the corrected Cu dispersion could be determined. The effect of Mg2+/Al3+ on Cu+/Cu0 species and selective hydrogenation activity was explored. In addition, the role of cationic Cu(I) species in LDHs derived CuMgAlO x on the alcohol selectivity and stability was evaluated. The balance between metallic Cu surface and cationic Cu(I) species for the production of long-chain alcohol was also highlighted. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Copper(II) nitrate trihydrate (Cu(NO3)2•3H2O, QREC, 99.50 %), magnesium nitrate hexahydrate (Mg(NO3)2•6H2O, PANREAC APPLICHEM, 98.00 %), aluminium nitrate nonahydrate (Al(NO3)3•9H2O, PANREAC APPLICHEM, 98.00 %), sodium hydroxide anhydrous pellets (NaOH, CARLO ERBA, 98.00 %), sodium carbonate anhydrous (Na2CO3, CARLO ERBA, 99.50 %), methanol (CH3OH, CARLO ERBA, 99.9 %), methyl palmitate (C17H32O2, SIGMA-ALDRICH, 97.00 %), n-dodecane (C12H26, CARLO ERBA, 99.90 %), n-octane (C8H18, CARLO ERBA, 99.00 %), and n-heptane (C7H16, CARLO ERBA, 99.00 %), were purchased and used without further purification. Hydrogen (99.99 %), nitrogen (99.99 %), air (zero grade, 99.99 %), 10 % hydrogen in argon (99.98 %), and helium (99.999 %) were ordered from UIG company. 1 % hydrogen in argon (99.98 %), and 1 % ammonia in helium (99.99 %) were ordered from Linde. 2.2 Sample preparation Cu containing layered double hydroxides (CuLDHs, ∼17 wt.%) was prepared from co-precipitation and hydrothermal methods, as previously reported [32], with the different Mg2+/Al3+ ratios. A fixed amount of copper(II) nitrate trihydrate (Cu(NO3)2•3H2O) (2.20 g) was used for all samples. The mass of magnesium nitrate hexahydrate (Mg(NO3)2•6H2O) and aluminum nitrate nonahydrate ((Al(NO3)3•9H2O) employed for the respective samples were 6.32:9.25, 7.12:8.33, 7.83:7.50, and 8.77:6.42 for CuMg60Al40O x , CuMg70Al30O x , CuMg75Al25O x , and CuMg80Al20O x , respectively. The mixture of metal precursors was dissolved in 200 mL of methanolic solution (50 %v/v, MeOH in H2O), referred to as solution A. Meanwhile, 0.0142 g/mL of sodium carbonate (Na2CO3) and 0.0177 g/mL of sodium hydroxide (NaOH) were mixed thoroughly in 200 mL of methanolic solution (solution B) to control the pH during the CuLDHs formation. Subsequently, solutions A and B were added dropwise (2 mL/min) into 200 mL methanolic solution under vigorous stirring. The pH of the mixture solution was maintained at 10±0.3. The suspension was stirred at the same pH for an additional 10 min. The slurry was then transferred into an HDPE bottle (1 L) and aged at 65 °C for 24 h without stirring. The solid underwent aging, filtration, and washing with DI water until neutral pH. The resulting CuLDHs solid was dried at 90 °C for 24 h and denoted as CuMgAlO x -pre. To obtain mixed metal oxide catalysts, the CuMgAlO x -pre were calcined under air (60 mL/min) at 550 °C (2 °C /min) for 12 h, denoted as CuMgAlO x . Prior to catalytic testing, all CuMgAlO x catalysts were reduced at 250 °C under H2 gas flow (60 mL/min) for 2 h. 2.3 Material characterization The surface area was determined using an N2 adsorption-desorption analyzer (TOP200, Altermira instruments), following the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method. Briefly, ∼50 mg of samples was evacuated at 100 °C for 12 h, and then nitrogen was introduced at −196 °C for the N2 adsorption-desorption experiment. Copper (Cu), magnesium (Mg), and aluminum (Al) contents were determined using inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES, Avio 500 Max, PerkinElmer). The sample (∼0.05 g) was digested in a solution mixture of 30 mL sulfuric acid (H2SO4) and 15 mL nitric acid (HNO3). The mixture was then heated at 210 °C for 12 h with a heating rate of 2 °C/min. After digestion, the solution was filtered and diluted with deionized water. The weight loss of the samples was evaluated using a thermogravimetric analyzer (TGA/DSC1, Mettler Toledo). Roughly, ∼30 mg of a sample was placed in a micro crucible and heated under N2 from 50 to 900 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. The structural identity and crystallite sizes of all samples were measured by X-ray powder diffraction (XRD, SmartLab, Rigaku), using Cu K α 1.54441 Å, Kβ filter 1D for Cu (0.4970) with a step width of 0.0100°, and a speed of 50°/min. The acquisition time was set to 2 min. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) using a TECNAI G2 20 (FEI) and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) mapping images was employed to investigate the topology of the catalyst. ∼10 mg of the sample was dispersed in ethanol and sonicated for 1 min. Following sonication, 50 µL of the solution was deposited onto a nickel grid supported by a carbon film and then allowed to dry under ambient conditions. The NH3 temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) was conducted using a custom-made instrument to assess the acid strength and acidity of the samples with 1 % NH3/Ar, which was equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (VICI, Valco instrument). Prior to the experiment, ∼50 mg of the CuMgAlO x catalyst was reduced at 250 °C for 2 h (10 °C/min) under H2. After cooling down to room temperature, it was exposed to 1 % NH3/Ar for 1 h (60 mL/min) and flushed with He gas (1 h) to remove excess NH3. Finally, the desorption of NH3 (NH3-TPD) was detected from 50 to 900 °C. The TCD signal was recorded in both the heating and cooling steps and calibrated using HZSM-5 as a standard. The reducibility of samples was determined by the temperature program reduction (H2-TPR) using a custom-made instrument equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (VICI, Valco instrument). First, CuMgAlO x sample (∼50 mg) was calcined in air (60 mL/min) at 550 °C (2 °C/min) for 12 h, then cooled down to room temperature under N2. Subsequently, it was heated under 10 % H2/Ar from 80 to 900 °C (10 °C/min). The TCD signal was recorded in both the heating and cooling steps and calibrated using CuO as a standard. Additionally, a standard pulse containing 1 % H2/Ar gas was injected after each H2-TPR analysis. The dissociated N2O adsorption technique was employed to estimate Cu dispersion [40]. This method is analogous to H2-TPR. After calcination at 550 °C (2 °C/min), the first H2-TPR was performed from 80 °C to 350 °C (10 °C/min) under 10 % H2/Ar (60 mL/min) and held at 350 °C for 2 h, obtaining the first H2-consumption. At this step, all copper species were reduced. Then, the sample was cooled down to 60 °C under N2, and the catalyst surfaces were oxidized using N2O (60 mL/min) at 60 °C for 1 h. After that, an excess N2O was subsequently flushed out with N2 gas at 100 °C for 1 h. The sample was then cooled down to room temperature. A secondary H2-TPR was conducted, similarly to the first H2-TPR. The hydrogen consumption of the primary and secondary H2-TPR could be used to calculate the dispersion of copper on the surface. The dispersion of Cu was determined using the equation presented in Fig. S1 [40]. The consecutive H2-TPR measurements were performed using a custom-made instrument equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (VICI, Valco instrument) to determine the reversible interconversion of Cu+/Cu+-H species in the samples. First, approximately 50 mg of the CuMgAlO x sample was ground to a 20-mesh particle size, packed into a quartz tube, and placed in the reactor's heating zone. The sample was then recalcined under an air flow of 60 mL/min at 550 °C, with a heating rate of 2 °C/min, for 12 h. After calcination, the sample was cooled to room temperature under a nitrogen atmosphere. Next, the sample was heated under a 10 % H2/Ar flow, increasing the temperature from 80 °C to 350 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min and held at 350 °C for 2 h to obtain the first H2 consumption. The system was then purged with nitrogen at 60 mL/min and left at room temperature for 24 h without exposure to air. After this, the heating process was repeated under the same conditions, again using a flow of 10 % H2/Ar from 80 °C to 350 °C, holding at 350 °C for 2 h to obtain the second H2 consumption. This process was repeated for the third and fourth measurements. In situ H2 evolution experiment was performed to confirm the reversible interconversion. Approximately 5–6 mg of the catalyst was subjected to pretreatment under a mixed O2/N2 flow (12 mL/min O2 and 48 mL/min N2) at 400 °C for 2 h. Following this, the sample was cooled to room temperature under N2 (48 mL/min). After that, the sample was reduced under 10 % H2 in N2 (60 mL/min) 250 °C for 2 h with the heating rate of 10 °C/min. Then, the sample was cooled to room temperature under N2 (48 mL/min). Post-reduction, residual hydrogen in the gas phase was purged by flowing N2 at 60 mL/min until hydrogen was no longer detected in the effluent. Temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) experiments were conducted by heating the catalyst from room temperature to 400 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min under an N2 flow of 60 mL/min. The system was held at 400 °C for 30 min. Throughout the process, concentrations of hydrogen (mass 2), nitrogen (mass 28), and water (mass 18) were continuously monitored using a quadrupole mass spectrometer (PFEIFFER VACUUM - PrismaPlus® QMG 220 F with Faraday detector), calibrated against standard mixtures. In situ time-resolved X-ray absorption near edge spectroscopy (in situ TR-XANES) was performed at BL2.2: TRXAS, Synchrotron Light Research Institute (SLRI), Thailand to determine the Cu species (Cu0/Cu+). An energy-dispersive monochromator and position-sensitive detector were employed to perform XANES measurement. The Cu K-edge XANES spectra were collected using the integration time of 2000 ms with an average of 10 scans. The composition of Cu species on the catalysts was estimated by Linear Combination Fitting (LCF) over Athena software using Cu foil, Cu2O, CuO, and CuSO4 as a standard. The LCF was fit in the range of 8962–9042 eV, while E0 was not allowed to float. The fitting was forced to obtain the sum of total composition to one within R factor <0.05, using the Athena software of XANES spectra. 2.4 Catalytic testing The selective hydrogenation of methyl palmitate was carried out in a fixed-bed reactor under the atmospheric pressure of H2. Prior to performing the reaction, the catalyst precursor (CuMgAlO x -pre) was first calcined at 550 °C under air (60 mL/min). Then, 0.25 g of the CuMgAlO x catalyst was packed in the reactor and recalcined under air (60 mL/min) at 550 °C for 12 h. It was subsequently treated under H2 with a flow rate of 60 mL/ min at 250 °C for 2 h. After that, 10 % w/w methyl palmitate (MP) in n-dodecane was introduced at a feed rate of 2.4 mL/h at 250 °C under H2 (180 mL/min). The reactor outlet was heated at 70 °C to prevent product solidification and collected to analyze by gas chromatography (GC-FID) using a DB-1 capillary column. Conversion, yield, selectivity, hydrogenation activity, and alcohol production rate were calculated by the following equation: MP conversion ( % ) = mol of M P 0 − mol of M P t mol of M P 0 × 100 Yield ( % ) = mol of product A t mol of M P 0 × 100 Selectivity ( % ) = Yield of product A ( % ) MP conversion ( % ) × 100 Hydrogenation rate ( mmolfeed / h · gcat ) = mmol of converted MP ( mmol / h ) weight of catalyst ( g ) Alcohol production rate ( h − 1 ) = weight of hexadecanol production ( g / h ) weight of catalyst ( g ) Mass balance ( % ) = Total yield Conversion × 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterizations XRD patterns of Cu containing layered double hydroxides samples, CuMgAlO x -pre (Fig. 1 ) with the various M2+/M3+ molar ratios from 2.2 to 4.8 (Table 1 ) showed the LDHs characteristic diffraction peaks similar to those reported in the literature [41]. The 2θ values at 11°, 24°, 35°, 38°, 46°, 60°, and 62° corresponded to Mg-Al LDHs phases (Fig. S2) at 003, 006, 009, 105, 108, 110 and 113, respectively. Since no crystalline phases of MgO, CuO, or Al2O3 were observed, the incorporated Cu2+ likely substituted Mg2+ in the cationic octahedral layers, which were sandwiched by anionic layers (CO3 2− and water), as shown in Scheme 1 . Moreover, a slightly broader peak indicating the lower and smaller crystallite size, was obtained (Fig. 1) when the Al content increases (in other words Mg content decreases) from CuMg80Al20O x to CuMg60Al40O x (Table S1). In fact, Table 2 shows that CuMg60Al40O x has a crystallite size of ∼8 nm, while CuMg70Al30O x , CuMg75Al25O x , and CuMg80Al20O x for whitin the range of ∼11–12 nm. This is presumably because a lower M2+/M3+ molar ratio of CuMg60Al40O x (2.23, Table 1) contains fewer M2+ species than conventional LDHs (Mg6Al2(OH)16CO3, M2+/M3+ = 3). Hence, the octahedral sheets would contain relatively more Al3+, resulting in cationic layers with a higher positive charge. Accordingly, more exchangeable anionic species must be counterbalanced, and higher water content would be retained in the interlayers. Thus, a more labile structure would be obtained for CuLDHs with high Al content. In line with this view, the initial weight loss (50–200 °C), presumably from the absorbed water (Table 2 and Fig. S3) increases with the Al contents (CuMg80Al20O x < CuMg75Al25O x < CuMg70Al30O x < CuMg60Al40O x ). The carbonate content was derived from TGA at 200–500 °C, decomposition of interlayered carbonates and 500–700 °C for decomposition of highly stable carbonates, Table 2. It is noted that all samples were similar range (∼24–28 wt.%), suggesting that the hydroxides (OH−) would be increased to counterbalance the cationic layers with higher Al contents. Accordingly, the higher water content would be obtained, presumably due to the higher hydrogen bonding within highly polarized interlayers. Thus, the water content is inversely proportional to the (Cu2++Mg2+)/Al3+ molar ratio. After calcination at 550 °C, the collapse of the LDHs structure was observed for all samples (Fig. 2 a). The surface area is in the range of 100–150 m2/g with the interparticle void of 32–36 nm was observed for typical CuMgAlO x catalysts (Table 1, Fig. S4) [35,42–45]. Only the periclase (MgO) peaks were detected in the XRD at 2θ = 35°, 43°, and 64°. The peak intensity increases with the increase in M2+/M3+ molar ratio (CuMg60Al40O x < CuMg70Al30O x < CuMg75Al25O x < CuMg80Al20O x ) due to the increase in Mg2+ content (Table 1). Interestingly, neither crystalline peaks of CuO nor Al2O3 were observed despite the high Cu and Al content (∼17 wt.%, 7–11 wt.%, respectively). This indicates that the Cu2+ and Al3+ species could be highly dispersed over MgO crystallites. Since the Cu2+ and Al3+ species in CuLDHs are discretely located in the octahedral sites, the strong Cu interaction of Cu2+-MgO or Cu2+-Al2O3 would be expected, preventing CuO agglomeration after the calcination, as also mentioned in the literature [35]. A higher Al3+ content not only decreases the crystallinity of the CuMgAlO x but also suppresses the reducibility of Cu2+ species, as seen from H2-TPR in Fig. 3 . At high Al3+ content, the broad reduction peak of Cu2+ to Cu0 was observed at ∼253 °C for CuMg60Al40O x and CuMg70Al30O x (Fig. 3i and ii). On the other hand, a lower reduction temperature (∼222–225 °C, Fig. 3iii and iv) was detected for MgO-rich samples (CuMg75Al25O x and CuMg80Al20O x ). This could be attributed to the stronger interaction between Cu2+ and Al3+ (presumably Cu2+-Al2O3) than Cu2+ and Mg2+ (Cu2+-MgO) [46]. In a supportive manner, a high reduction temperature (249 °C) was reported for Cu-impregnated Al2O3 (Cu/Al2O3) [47], while Cu doped on MgO (Cu/MgO) showed a reduction temperature at ∼215 °C as in Fig. S5. Despite the higher Cu2+ reduction temperatures of CuMgAlO x samples with lower M2+/M3+ molar ratios, the highly dispersed Cu particles were obtained for all samples. None of the metallic Cu phases were detected in the XRD even at this high Cu loading (∼17 wt.%, Fig. 2b). TEM analysis showed the ultrafine Cu nanoparticles highly dispersed on the folded sheet structures of mixed oxides, as depicted in Fig. 4 . This could indicate that, after the calcination, the lamellar structure of Cu2+ oxide may well be disintegrated within the collapsed LDH layers, due to the strong interaction between Cu and Al2O3. Then, the ruptured Cu2+ oxide sheets would be reduced to Cu nanoparticles within the confined mixed oxide matrix. In line with this view, the exceptionally high Cu dispersion (>70 %, determined by the N2O-dissociative reaction in Fig. 5 ) was obtained from all samples. Moreover, the Cu dispersion (72 % to 93 %, Table 1) was increased with Mg2+ content (CuMg60Al40O x to CuMg80Al20O x ). The amount of H2 consumption in H2-TPR is equivalent to the Cu loadings assuming that all Cu2+ species are completely reduced to Cu0 (Table 1). However, the in situ time-resolved X-ray absorption near-edge spectroscopy (in situ TR-XANES) of CuMg75Al25O x evidences the large fraction of Cu+ species (Fig. 6 ). It can be seen that the Cu K-edge energy of the reduced sample appears at 8983.2 eV with a pre-edge feature of 8980.6 eV, which is relatively close to the value of the Cu2O standard. The linear combination fitting (LCF) indicated that the in situ reduced CuMg75Al25O x still contained 70 % of Cu+ species with only 30 % of metallic Cu species despite the reduction at 250 °C for 2 h. One could expect that the samples with 70 % Cu+ species would consume much lower H2. The inconsistency between the H2 consumption and the presence of remaining Cu+ species in the reduced sample implied that the formed Cu+ species could further dissociate H2 to form copper(I) hydride (Cu+-H) species upon the reduction (Scheme 2 ). Accordingly, the reduction of Cu2+ to form Cu+-H would consume 1 equivalence mole of H2. Nevertheless, the produced Cu+-H species are relatively unstable and could reversibly decompose into Cu+ and H2 under an inert atmosphere so-called “reversible interconversion” [38,39]. To prove the reversible interconversion of Cu+/Cu+-H species, the samples were subjected to H2-TPR at 350 °C for 2 h, then purged under N2 at room temperature for 24 h. Without exposing the sample to air, the consecutive H2-TPR was performed. As expected, none of the secondary H2 consumption was observed for the typical CuO since the metallic Cu was completely formed during the 1st H2-TPR (Fig. 7 i). In sharp contrast, all CuMgAlO x samples showed a secondary H2 consumption at a relatively lower temperature (150–160 °C, Fig. 7ii–v) than the first reduction temperature (220–250 °C). The secondary reduction is in the same range for reducing surface Cu2O (∼150 °C) as observed in the N2O-dissociative reaction profiles (Fig. 5). The observed secondary H2 consumption without exposing the sample to air suggested that the lamellar structure of Cu2+ oxide could be reduced to the metallic Cu and Cu+-H species during the 1st H2-TPR (Scheme 2). After purging under N2, the Cu+-H (species III) could decompose into Cu+ (species IV) and H2. Accordingly, the secondary H2 consumption for Cu+ was evidenced to regenerate Cu+-H species at a lower temperature. This process can be repeated for at least three consecutive cycles with the same H2 consumption (0.91 mmol/g in Fig. 8 ), emphasizing the reversible interconversion of Cu+/Cu+-H of all CuMgAlO x samples. In addition, the evolution of H2 from the Cu+-H species was detected using a quadrupole mass spectrometer (Q-MS) on the reduced CuMg75Al25O x during heating. This observation is illustrated in Fig. S6. The amount of Cu+/Cu+-H can be quantified from the secondary H2 consumption (A2) obtained during the reversible interconversion as represented in Eq. (1). Therefore, the Cu species remaining in CuMgAlO x can be determined from the combination of H2-TPR, N2O-TPR, and consecutive H2-TPR with the calculation described above. From Table 3, all CuMgAlO x samples contain relatively high amounts of Cu+/Cu+-H species (50–86 %). The higher the Mg2+ content the higher the amount of Cu+/Cu+-H species and the lower the metallic Cu species. This could indicate that the importance of Cu2+-MgO interaction in CuMgAlO x that allows Cu2+ species to disperse and share the same lattice parameter as MgO, evidenced by the XRD. This prevents the formation of the bulk CuO and Cu-Al2O3 (copper aluminate) after the calcination. Even though the metallic Cu content decreased, the Cu metal dispersion increased with the increase in Mg2+ content. This again suggested that the strong interaction Cu2+-MgO at a high Mg2+ content led to the smaller metallic Cu particle (presumably Cu clusters), as evidenced by the lower reduction temperature in the H2-TPR (Fig. 5). 3.2 Selective hydrogenation of methyl palmitate The similar hydrogenation activity of CuMg60Al40O x and CuMg70Al30O x was observed (∼53–54 % conversion, Table 4 , entry 1–2), due to the similar Cu dispersion (∼40 %, Table 3). Hexadecanol (C16-OH, ∼42 % yield) was obtained as a main product (∼80 % selectivity). While only ∼6 % yield of hexadecanal (C16-al), ∼6 % yield of hexadecene (C16-1-ene) and iso-hexadecene (iso-C16-ene) was obtained. This clearly showed that CuMg60Al40O x and CuMg70Al30O x provided high selective hydrogenation of fatty acid methyl esters to alcohols. This could be attributed to the relatively high Cu+ content in these two samples which particularly promotes η 1-adsorption of CO that could undergo hydrogenation to an alcohol (Scheme 2). Furthermore, the weak interaction between the produced alcohol and Cu+ facilitates alcohol desorption. The Cu+ species also prevents alcohol re-adsorption and suppresses dehydration/isomerization to form hydrocarbon by-products. Only trace hexadecanal, the primary product (Scheme 3 ), was obtained over CuMg60Al40O x and CuMg70Al30O x . This could indicate that the hydrogenation rate of aldehydes would be faster than the esters, as mentioned in the literature [48]. Nevertheless, the observed hexadecene and iso-hexadecene suggested the dehydration-isomerization of hexadecanol, promoted by the acid sites, presumably the surface AlOH. In a supportive manner, a trace amount of acid sites (<10 µmol/g) in CuMg60Al40O x and CuMg70Al30O x were detected by NH3-TPD (Fig. S7). As the Mg2+/Al3+ ratio increased, a higher hydrogenation activity of CuMg75Al25O x (57 % conversion, Table 4 entry 3) was observed, as compared to those of CuMg60Al40O x and CuMg70Al30O x (∼53–54 % conversion). This could be attributed to the Cu dispersion of CuMg75Al25O x (85 %, Table 3, entry 3) than that of CuMg60Al40O x and CuMg70Al30O x (72–81 %). In line with this view, a lower C16-al (from ∼7 % to ∼3 %) was obtained, presumably due to a higher CO hydrogenation activity. The higher yield of C16-OH (∼10 %) was obtained with only a trace amount of C16-ene. This could be attributed to the higher Cu+/Cu+-H species in CuMg75Al25O x to desorb the alcohol and prevent its re-adsorption. However, the excess Cu+/Cu+-H species in CuMg80Al20O x led to a lower activity due to the relatively less metallic Cu (∼7 %). Accordingly, the lower C16-OH yield (28 %) was observed with only trace amount of C16-ene. Accordingly, a balance of active Cu surface (Cusurface) and cationic Cu(I) species (Cu+/Cu+-H species) appears to play an important role in the selective hydrogenation of methyl palmitate to hexadecanol. As the reducibility of the CuMgAlO x can be regulated by the Mg2+/Al3+ ratio (Fig. 3), the fraction of Cu surface and Cu+ species retained in each sample can be modulated (Table 3). The ratio between Cusurface and cationic Cu(I) species (Cu+/Cu+-H) would affect the selective hydrogenation activity, as shown in Fig. 9 . Even though cationic Cu(I) species govern the feed adsorption/activation and alcohol desorption, metallic Cu species are still required. The more metallic the Cu surface, the higher conversion, up to the Cusurface/Cu(I) ratio of 0.25. This can be attributed to the hydrogen dissociation ability of the available metallic Cu surface, in addition to Cu+/Cu+-H species that facilitate the feed adsorption/activation, as discussed earlier. However, the Cusurface/Cu(I) ratio above 0.25 leads to a decline in overall hydrogenation activity. This is presumably due to the limited cationic Cu(I) species to interact with the methyl palmitate, despite the sufficient metallic Cu surface. Comparing the hydrogenation in a flow reactor, the CuMg75Al25O x catalysts provide a much higher alcohol selectivity (∼90 %, Table 5 ) than other Cu-based catalysts (<60 %). Despite that competitive adsorption of alcohols can be generally facilitated in a flow system, the presence of the Cu+/Cu+-H species in CuMgAlO x can prevent the alcohol re-adsorption that leads to side reactions, i.e., dehydration, and isomerization. Moreover, the alcohol selectivity obtained in this study (∼90 %, Table 5) is comparable to those operated in the batch reactor (>80 %). This is because the alcohol re-adsorption is inhibited in a manner similar to the reaction in the liquid phase, where the alcohol re-adsorption is inhibited by much stronger adsorption of an ester-feed. This emphasizes the key role of cationic Cu(I) species (Cu+/Cu+-H) in the selective hydrogenation of esters to alcohols. In addition to the high alcohol selectivity, the CuMgAlO x catalysts provide relatively high stability (Figs. 10 and 11 ), as compared to other Cu-based catalysts, i.e., CuO [49], CuCr2O4 [50], Cu/SiO2 [30], 20CuPS [30], 0.05KCuPS [31], 1 %Pd–Cu(3:1)/diatomite [51], and Cu/m-ZrO2 [49], that generally suffer from deactivation. Especially, CuMg75Al25O x showed the steady conversion and yields over 100 h, as depicted in Fig. 11. This could be attributed to the high content of Cu+ species in these catalysts (>50 %, Table 3) that is reversibly interconverted to Cu+-H species under hydrogen. The reversible interconversion between Cu+ and Cu+-H allows the simultaneous hydrogen dissociation/evolution on the catalyst surface in a manner similar to that observed over Pd-based catalysts [52,53]. This phenomenon could prevent the hydrogen transfer from any carbon source (esters, alcohols, alkenes, etc.) that leads to the formation of carbonaceous deposits. Thus, the surface remains always available for feed adsorption/activation. 4 Conclusions Layered double hydroxides derived CuMgAlO x catalysts provide highly selective hydrogenation of fatty acid methyl esters (FAMEs) to fatty alcohol (up to 92 % selectivity) in a fixed-bed reactor under atmospheric H2. The lamellar structure of Cu2+ oxide in all CuLDHs samples was well disintegrated over the collapsed LDH layers after calcination, due to a strong interaction of Cu2+ with the confined mixed oxides. The ruptured Cu2+ oxide sheets were partially reduced to a mixture of cationic Cu(I) species and highly dispersed Cu nanoparticles. Cationic Cu(I) species show reversible interconversion of Cu+ and Cu+-H species under H2 due to the strong interaction with the confined mixed oxide sheets. The combination of H2-TPR, consecutive H2-TPR, and N2O-dissociative reaction allows the new approach to quantitatively determine the Cu species, including cationic Cu(I) species (Cu+/Cu+-H), metallic Cu, and Cusurface, which can be validated by the in situ TR-XANES. The higher the Mg2+ content (CuMg60Al40O x < CuMg70Al30O x < CuMg75Al25O x < CuMg80Al20O x ), the higher the amount of cationic Cu(I) species (54 % <66 % < 68 % < 86 %), and the higher Cu dispersion (72 % < 81 % < 85 %, ∼93 %). The cationic Cu(I) species in CuMgAlO x catalysts promote η 1-adsorption and hydrogenation of CO esters. They also prevent alcohol re-adsorption, leading to high fatty alcohol selectivity. Nevertheless, the hydrogenation activity depends on the balance between the Cusurface and cationic Cu(I) species. The optimal Cusurface/Cu(I) ratio of 0.25 (CuMg75Al25O x ) results in a hydrogenation rate of 1.53 mmol/h⋅gcat and an alcohol production rate of 49.3 h−1. The excessive cationic Cu(I) species (Cusurface/Cu(I) ratio < 0.25) lead to lower hydrogenation activity due to the limited Cu surface for hydrogen dissociation. The reversible interconversion between Cu+ and Cu+-H allows simultaneous hydrogen dissociation/evolution for high catalyst stability. coredata.dc:description: High fatty alcohol production (>90 % selectivity) can be achieved though the selective hydrogenation of fatty acid methyl esters over layered double hydroxide derived CuMgAlO x catalysts in a fixed-bed reactor at 250 °C under atmospheric H2. ∼17 wt.% Cu loading CuLDHs with different Mg2+/Al3+ ratios (CuMg60Al40O x , CuMg70Al30O x , CuMg75Al25O x , and CuMg80Al20O x ) were prepared by co-precipitation-hydrothermal method. The Cu dispersion and species were determined by H2-TPR, consecutive H2-TPR, N2O-dissociative reaction, and in situ TR-XANES. Highly dispersed Cu metal along with cationic Cu(I) species were obtained for all CuMgAlO x . The cationic Cu(I) species (Cu+/Cu+-H) content increased with Mg2+ content. In the presence of H2, the cationic Cu(I) species undergo reversible interconversion between Cu+ and Cu+-H species, facilitating hydrogen dissociation/evolution. The hydrogenation activity was governed by the balance of the metallic Cu surface and the cationic Cu(I) species. The Cu+ species allow preferential adsorption of CO ester for selective hydrogenation of FAMEs to fatty alcohol (>90 % selectivity). With Cusurface/Cu(I) ratio at 0.25 (CuMg75Al25O x ), the fatty alcohol production rate of 49.3 h−1 was obtained with high stability due to the reversible interconversion of Cu+/Cu+-H that prevented product re-adsorption and side reactions.

coredata.dc:title: Reversibly interconverted Cu+/Cu+-H species as active sites for selective hydrogenation of fatty acid methyl esters to fatty alcohol over layered double hydroxide derived CuMgAlO x catalysts
